posts.name: Caleb Lin
posts.cooked:
Hi, I need a bit of help. So I’ve been trying to code a swerve base . Basically, the issue I have is that even though WPILIB builds the code, when I try to deploy it to the RoboRio, driverstation doesn’t show that there is robot code (and there is none) There is no deploy message that stands out to be faulty (in my eyes, a red error), although it does say skipped deploying.

It does open the RioLog, but doesn’t do the prints that are normally there (the startup messages that I cannot recall).

The things I’ve tried: Messing around with build.gradle →

doing some include stuff from stackoverflow (because I thought maybe the issue was that I was using subfolders)

Changing the wpilib version to the one driverstation says

Copying the file from our 2023 robot code (which builds and deploys fine)

Removing the files from their folders

Creating a new project (which builds and deploys fine initially), and copying the files into it

^ None of this worked, the issue remained the same

However, Running it through simulation seems to work - the shuffleboard prints work out and the code doesn’t die. (I’m sure I disabled enable simulation afterwards)

Conclusion: I think it’s an issue with the c++ code itself, maybe I’ve made some egregious c++ mistake that prevents the code from deploying, but I have no idea what to look for.

(Ignore the shuffleboard folder in the github, it was a side idea/project - i did delete that while testing)

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: My first step would be running ./gradlew clean in your project’s root directory. After that, I’d run ./gradlew deploy --info so someone more knowledgeable in gradle has useful info.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: If you use the option in VS Code to enable desktop support, you can run your code in simulation. Your code is likely crashing on startup, which causes code to never show up on the robot. In C++, these crashes are much easier to debug on desktop.

OppositeShark:

There is no deploy message that stands out to be faulty (in my eyes, a red error), although it does say skipped deploying.

What does it say exactly?
They said in simulation it didn’t crash.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
In SwerveDrive you’re using an uninitialized variable during construction: the constructor calls reset() which calls zero() which calls a function on navx_, which is not initialized. swerve/SwerveDrive.cpp at master · linc-mvla/swerve · GitHub

I’m not sure why this doesn’t crash in sim too (this is UB, and different compilers can do unpredictably different things, but still).

posts.name: Caleb Lin
posts.cooked: Thank you! (and everyone else who helped out) I’m running into other issues now but is a bit less confusing. I might’ve mixed up when I ran the simulation, perhaps before adding the navx.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Also, “Debug Robot Code” is your friend in this type of situation.
